title: 113_hr3159
content: The Act is titled the "Ensuring Adversarial Process in the FISA Court Act" and it establishes public interest advocates for proceedings under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978. The "Ensuring Adversarial Process in the FISA Court Act" amends the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 to appoint public interest advocates in proceedings before various courts under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978. The Board, in subparagraph (A), consults with the Attorney General, appoints non-government attorneys with expertise in privacy and civil liberties, considers candidates committed to constitutional protections, and ensures availability for court appearances. The Board appoints non-government attorneys with expertise in privacy and civil liberties, ensuring their ability to obtain security clearance for participation in matters before the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court. Notice is provided to the Attorney General and the presiding judge of all appointments. The Board appoints non-government attorneys with expertise in privacy and civil liberties to carry out duties as public interest advocates under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. Technical experts are also appointed to assist the advocates in their duties. The Board appoints non-government attorneys with expertise in technical issues related to the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, including computer networks, telecommunications, encryption, and cybersecurity. The Attorney General compensates these attorneys at the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level III of the Executive Schedule. The Attorney General provides travel expenses for attorneys appointed under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, in accordance with applicable provisions. The President ensures that appointed attorneys and experts receive security clearances promptly. Attorneys appointed under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act are promptly given security clearances to carry out their duties, as long as they meet the criteria. The term 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court' refers to the court established under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court of Review, established under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978, appoints attorneys with security clearances to serve as public interest advocates. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board must appoint at least one attorney within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court appoints public interest advocates in matters involving significant interpretations of the law, including issues related to the Fourth Amendment. These advocates are appointed under the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court appoints public interest advocates under the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 to represent privacy and civil liberties interests in court matters. The appointed advocate participates fully in the case and represents the people's interests. The public interest advocate appointed by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court represents the interests of the people of the United States in preserving privacy and civil liberties, has access to relevant evidence, can file motions and briefs, and request rehearing or en banc consideration. The court may request a rehearing or en banc consideration of a decision. In cases with a public interest advocate appointed, if the court believes there is a substantial difference of opinion on a legal question, it can request review by another court or the Supreme Court. The court may request a rehearing or en banc consideration of a decision. In matters where a court certifies a ruling for review, the United States and public interest advocate can provide written briefs. The covered court can also allow amicus curiae participation, including in oral arguments, if deemed appropriate. The Attorney General must ensure that public interest advocates have necessary resources for their work. The covered court, including judges from various subsections, has access to necessary office space, materials, and technology for full participation in legal matters.
